description.narrative: The DRCJR 2021 will continue to provide multi-sectoral assistance and sustainable solutions in response to community-identified life-saving needs and protection risks through close collaboration and coordination in the Eastern Zone of DRC. Under the DRCJR, multi-sectoral assistance is understood as an individual or community receiving a humanitarian assistance package of at least three sectors.

The overall objective of the DRCJR2 was to provide multi-sectoral assistance to respond to the immediate needs and protection risks of the most vulnerable and conflict affected people in targeted Territories within North- and South Kivu in DRC, through an effective and efficient humanitarian response by Dutch NGOs, local partners and actors.
The the need for a multi-sectoral approach remains as the need has, in effect, grown across all sectors. Therefore the DRCJR 3 will build on existing collaborations in areas with continuing high levels of needs

While last year the JR partners targeted three Priority 1 health zones and three Priority 2 health zones, with increased humanitarian needs, the DRCJR 2021 partners have chosen to work solely in priority 1 HZ as identified in September 2020 .
DRCJR3 interventions target both IDPs, returnees and host communities, dependent on the local context at Territory level. Specific focus will be on those groups that remain most vulnerable, namely children, women (who are at daily risk of (gender-based) violence and abuse) and people with specific needs.
